title: Disney's Missing 'Simpsons' Episode in Hong Kong Raises Censorship Fears; Episode that references the Tiananmen Square massacre is left out of the recently launched Disney+ streaming lineup
text:
Yet one episode is missing from "The Simpsons" lineup: Titled "Goo Goo Gai Pan," the episode from season 16 centers on a trip to China by the show's namesake family. Along the way they encounter a plaque at Tiananmen Square in Beijing that reads: "On this site, in 1989, nothing happened."

The episode also features a reference to the iconic "Tank Man" photo, in which a man stands in front of a column of tanks after the military moved in to crush student-led protests on June 4, 1989.

It isn't known if Disney removed the episode under pressure, or whether it decided itself to leave the episode out of its lineup when it launched the Disney+ service in Hong Kong earlier in November. Representatives for Disney didn't respond to requests for comment. A spokeswoman for the Hong Kong Office of the Communications Authority, which oversees broadcasters in the city, declined to comment.

The episode's absence fuels concerns about rising censorship in Hong Kong, and the extent to which Western companies are under pressure to assist in the effort or to self-censor following the imposition of a sweeping national security law by Beijing last year that has stamped out dissent across the city. In October, Hong Kong's legislature passed a film censorship law allowing the government to ban films deemed a threat to national security.

"Whether it's self-censorship or whether it's direct censorship, it is based on the calculation of how significant the China market is to Disney, or any other American company," said Steve Tsang, director of the SOAS China Institute in London. "It is about the China market. And the clear understanding that the Chinese government will not hesitate to use its economic muscle based on the size of its market to get its way."

Disney has huge business interests in China, a market that it and other Hollywood studios are careful not to offend for fear of losing access. Disney, with resorts in China and Hong Kong and extensive sales from its movie business in the region, has moved aggressively to maintain the peace with China over the years, a fact that has brought it some controversy in the U.S.

In 2016, Disney opened Shanghai Disney Resort, a $5.5 billion theme park and entertainment complex that took more than a decade of negotiations with Chinese authorities to mount. The company operates a smaller park in Hong Kong, while its Marvel Studios releases are among China's highest-grossing movies of all time.

Yet the company has run afoul of Chinese authorities before. Last year, for example, Disney executives had to defend the decision to film portions of a new "Mulan" remake in Xinjiang province, where the Chinese government is believed to house work camps for members of the Uyghur minority. The controversy prompted Chinese authorities to block marketing for the film, which ended up flopping in both Chinese and U.S. theaters.

The missing "Simpsons" episode satirizes the taboo nature in China of the 1989 killings of protesters in Tiananmen Square by the People's Liberation Army. In Hong Kong the massacre was openly commemorated for years, most notably during an annual candlelight vigil in the city's Victoria Park that routinely drew tens of thousands, until the national security crackdown.

In the past year and a half, authorities in Hong Kong have banned gatherings commemorating the massacre, citing pandemic restrictions. Organizers closed down a museum dedicated to the event following a visit from police. Officials at Hong Kong University have warned that they plan to remove a prominent statue commemorating the victims from a campus courtyard.

Meanwhile, authorities have shown a willingness to impose yearslong jail sentences on activists found guilty of chanting or displaying political slogans forbidden under the national security law. Earlier in November, a judge sentenced a former food-delivery worker to nearly six years in prisonfor promoting Hong Kong independence after he was arrested for chanting protest slogans during gatherings last year.

Authorities say the security law has brought safety and stability to Hong Kong following the sometimes violent wave of pro-democracy protests that rocked the city in 2019.

Erich Schwartzel contributed to this article.
